articles.title: JANUARY 1988
articles.summary: This document outlines an astronomical society's events for January and early February 1988. It details a general meeting featuring a presentation on "Return to Ayers Rock" by Ernie Piini, two astronomical observation field expeditions to Fremont State Park, a board meeting, and an introductory astronomy class. The schedule also includes a general meeting and a field expedition for February.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article announces two key events: the January 9th general meeting featuring astrophotographer Ernie Piini, who will present on observing and astrophotography of Southern Celestial Treasures from Australia. It also details the start of the SJAA's Introductory Observational Astronomy Class on January 30th, a 10-month program covering constellations, asterisms, and various amateur astronomy topics like telescope making, astrophotography, and celestial coordinate systems.

articles.title: Planetarium
articles.summary: A free planetarium class is being offered to the public, focusing on circumpolar constellations like Ursa Major, Ursa Minor, and Cassiopeia, as well as the winter group around Orion. The session will also explore various types of celestial objects observable, with no fee or membership required, and provides a contact for inquiries.

articles.title: FREE ASTRONOMY COMPUTER CONFERENCE
articles.summary: The article announces a free Astronomy Computer Bulletin Board Conference, accessible via personal computer and modem, where users can share observing experiences and equipment notes. This service, provided by SJAA members and Bay Area computer hobbyists, offers multiple dial-up numbers and a contact for additional information.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document is a classifieds section featuring various used astronomical telescopes and accessories for sale. It includes listings for Celestron, Meade, Tinsley, and custom-built telescopes, ranging from refractors and reflectors to Schmidt-Cassegrain and Cassegrain models, along with details on included accessories, pricing, and contact information for sellers.

articles.title: BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: This article provides an astronomical observing guide for January, detailing several celestial events and targets. It covers two meteor showers (Coma Berenicides and Quadrantids), key lunar terminator timings on features like the Straight Wall and Plato, and ephemeris for minor planets Egeria, Amphitrite, and Vesta. Additionally, it highlights specific Galilean satellite events for Jupiter and encourages early observations of Mars as it gains altitude.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: The article reports on recent comet activity, detailing three new discoveries and two recoveries. It mentions Comet Mueller's newly determined periodic orbit, which brings it to magnitude 17, and highlights several brighter comets—Bradfield, Borrelly, and McNaught—that are currently visible with small binoculars in various parts of the sky.

articles.title: Newly-discovered Comet Furuyama
articles.summary: This article details several newly discovered or recovered comets in late 1987, including Comet Furuyama, Comet Ichimura, Periodic Comet Longmore, Periodic Comet Temple 1, and Comet Shoemaker. It provides information on their discovery circumstances, estimated magnitudes, orbital characteristics, and visibility predictions for observers over the coming months. Notably, Comet Furuyama was discovered by an amateur astronomer, marking the ninth such find of the year.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This document provides ephemerides for two comets, Comet McNaught (1987b1) and Comet Bradfield (1987s), spanning from late December 1987 to early February 1988. It lists daily observational data including Right Ascension, Declination, elongation from the sun, and magnitude, accompanied by notes on their visibility and movement for Northern Hemisphere observers. The notes describe when and where to observe each comet, including their apparent paths through the sky and distances from Earth and the sun.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p)
articles.summary: Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p) is making one of its best appearances, remaining within 1 AU through mid-February and appearing large and diffuse. The article provides an observing guide with positional data (RA, Declination, Magnitude) for late December through early February, noting its trajectory from the southern sky to nearly overhead in the early evening. Observers are encouraged to view this 6.86-year periodic comet soon.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE
articles.summary: This 'SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE' details recent developments across several international space initiatives. Key updates include subscale tests for the redesigned space shuttle booster joint, NASA awarding contracts for the Space Station hardware, and an ongoing debate within the U.S. government regarding future space policy goals. Additionally, the Mir space station crew is preparing to return, the European Space Agency approved new space development programs, and Vice President George Bush endorsed specific recommendations from the Ride Report.

articles.title: AN OVERVIEW OF OBSERVING SITES
articles.summary: This article provides a detailed overview of Chesbro Reservoir as a recommended close-in observing site for astronomy, particularly suitable for winter, southwest of San Jose. It offers precise driving directions from a specific intersection and identifies alternative observing spots nearby, while noting that the popular Calero Reservoir is closed after dark.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT BY JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article describes a new potential amateur astronomy observing site at the Chesbro Reservoir parking lot, detailing its features like parking capacity, horizon views, light pollution sources, and amenities. Additionally, it discusses the Great Red Spot (GRS) on Jupiter, explaining discrepancies in transit time predictions due to differing assumed GRS longitudes and the complexities of Jupiter's longitude systems.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PST
articles.summary: This document provides a schedule of dates and times in Pacific Standard Time (PST) for the Great Red Spot (GRS) on Jupiter transiting the central meridian. The listed times cover a period from early January through early February. This resource is valuable for observers planning to view or image Jupiter's most famous storm.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, featuring guest speakers on a wide range of astronomical topics and informal "Indoor Star Parties." These gatherings offer a friendly atmosphere for enthusiasts of astrophotography, deep sky observation, telescope making, or general observing. The article provides detailed directions and meeting times for attendees.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Monthly indoor star parties offer amateur astronomers a chance to gather, share their passion for astronomy, and socialize. These events encourage members to bring telescopes and accessories, feature astrophotography slideshows, and may include impromptu observing sessions if weather permits. They also host SJAA board meetings and an introductory astronomy workshop.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays near the New Moon. These field expeditions take place at various designated locations, ranging from sites close to San Jose to distant places like Yosemite National Park. Attendees should consult the EPHEMERIS for directions and event details.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a popular destination for Bay Area amateur astronomers, offering serious deep sky observing and astrophotography, particularly during New Moon weekends, often attracting 50-100 telescopes. The park is home to the Fremont Peak Observatory Association's 30-inch telescope, which is open to the public on selected weekends. The article also provides detailed directions to the park and lists the officers and board members of the San Jose Astronomical Association, which publishes 'EPHEMERIS' monthly.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership types, including "Membership Only," "Membership/S&T," and "Junior (Under 18)," along with their respective fees. The form provides fields for applicant details and instructions for submission either at an SJAA meeting or by mail to the treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document features an optional questionnaire designed to gather information about an individual's astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas of expertise. It also includes postal information for the "SJAA EPHEMERIS," identifying it as a piece of mailed news material from a non-profit organization located in San Jose, CA.
